title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.2: DEMAND FOR QUALITY Maternal, Neonatal, and Child Health (MNCH), Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF) AND HYGIENE INTERVENTIONS

description.narrative: Output 1.2: By 2023, parents and caregivers have increased capacity to practice and demand quality Maternal, Neonatal, and Child Health (MNCH), infant and young child feeding (IYCF) and hygiene interventions, which contributes to Climate Change, Disaster Risks And Envionmental Degradation, Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices (Covid), Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 1:By 2023, young children (0 to 9 years), particularly the most vulnerable, benefit from gender responsive health, nutrition and early learning services.

participating-org.narrative: LESOTHO GOV HEALTH SECTOR REFORM UNICEF MALUTI SPECIAL

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.2: By 2023, parents and caregivers have increased capacity to practice and demand quality MNCH, infant and young childfeeding (IYCF) and hygiene interventions

description.narrative: UNICEF Lesotho strengthened the nutrition policy environment through an investment case study to inform advocacy towards an annual allocation of 3.5% of GDP to avert stunting.; Also, a total of 26,919 mothers and caregivers were reached with IYCF community services, and 17 842 children aged 6 to 23 months received micronutrient powder. In addition, UNICEF supported the Government to strengthen sector coordination, enhanced water supply in rural areas by rehabilitating/constructing 79 water supply systems benefitting 101 321 people, improved hand hygiene in 858 schools, and reached; 152,272 people in communities with hygiene messaging, supplies, and infrastructure. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:14/12/2021
